topics.definition: A business model that enables firms or individuals to conduct business over electronic networks, typically the internet, replacing traditional mail-order purchasing.
key_points: Allows buying and selling of goods/services online.
Includes retail stores, auction sites, banking services, ticket booking platforms.
Provides convenience but requires safety precautions.
processes: Customer visits an e-commerce website.
Selects product/service and adds to cart.
Proceeds to checkout, makes payment via digital means.
Product is delivered to the customer's address.
examples: www.bookadda.com – online bookstore
www.ebay.in – auction site
IRCTC – railway ticket booking
facts: E-commerce reduces geographical barriers.
Payment methods include credit/debit cards, net banking, digital wallets.
Risks include data theft, fraud, and misuse of card details.

topics.definition: Guidelines to protect users from online fraud and data theft while transacting on e-commerce platforms.
key_points: Use credit cards with low borrowing limits for online transactions.
Check for secure websites (https:// and lock icon).
Avoid public computers for financial transactions.
Keep records of all online transactions.
processes: Verify website authenticity before entering personal/financial details.
Never share PIN, CVV, or OTP with anyone.
Regularly monitor bank statements for unauthorized transactions.
examples: Checking privacy policy before shopping.
Memorizing CVV and erasing it from the card.
Using antivirus and firewall on personal devices.
facts: Banks never ask for card details via email.
Lottery winning emails are usually scams.
Data leakage can occur through malware or phishing.

topics.definition: Independent institutions established to regulate different segments of the financial system in India.
key_points: Reserve Bank of India (RBI) – regulates banking and monetary policy.
Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) – regulates securities and commodities markets.
Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority of India (IRDAI) – regulates insurance sector.
Pension Fund Regulatory and Development Authority (PFRDA) – regulates pension sector.
processes: RBI issues currency, acts as banker to government and banks, controls credit.
SEBI protects investor interests, promotes market development.
IRDAI ensures orderly growth of insurance sector.
PFRDA develops and regulates pension schemes like NPS.
examples: RBI head office – Mumbai
SEBI established – 1988 as administrative body, 1992 as statutory body
IRDAI head office – Hyderabad
facts: RBI was nationalized in 1949.
SEBI’s primary mandate is investor protection.
PFRDA was given statutory status in 2013.

topics.definition: Use of IT and digital platforms to enhance insurance services, distribution, claim processing, and customer support.
key_points: Enables online policy purchase, premium payment, and claim settlement.
Supports new distribution channels like tele-marketing, web aggregators.
Facilitates e-policies and insurance repositories.
processes: Customer compares policies online via web aggregators.
Pays premium digitally, receives e-policy in demat form.
Cashless claim settlement in network hospitals.
Grievances lodged and tracked via Integrated Grievance Management System (IGMS).
examples: Weather insurance for crops using weather data mapping.
IRDAI’s mobile app for comparing ULIPs.
V-Seva by Insurance Information Bureau (IIB) for vehicle insurance info.
facts: e-Policies eliminate paper and reduce storage risks.
Call centers and SMS services enhance customer support.
Online sales reduce commission costs, lowering premiums.

topics.definition: A grievance redressal mechanism for individual policyholders to resolve complaints against insurers out of court, in a cost-effective and impartial manner.
key_points: Handles complaints related to claim repudiation, premium disputes, delays, etc.
Complaint value must not exceed ₹20 lakh.
Ombudsman can give recommendations or awards.
processes: Policyholder approaches insurer first.
If unresolved in 30 days, complaint can be filed with Ombudsman.
Ombudsman acts as mediator; if mediation fails, passes an award within 3 months.
examples: 12 Ombudsman centers across India (Ahmedabad, Mumbai, Delhi, etc.).
Complaints about non-issuance of policy documents after premium payment.
facts: Award is binding on insurer but not on policyholder.
Policyholder can still approach Consumer Forum or court.
IRDAI does not act as appellate authority over Ombudsman decisions.

topics.definition: A market where contracts for future delivery of commodities are traded, helping manage price risks and discover future prices.
key_points: Includes ready delivery contracts (within 11 days) and forward contracts (beyond 11 days).
Regulated by SEBI under Forward Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1952.
Participants: hedgers, speculators, arbitrageurs.
processes: Farmers/producers use futures to lock in prices.
Contracts traded on commodity exchanges (like MCX).
Settlement occurs on a future date at predetermined price.
examples: Trading in gold, silver, crude oil, agricultural produce.
Hedgers: farmers, exporters; Speculators: traders seeking profit.
facts: Helps in price discovery and price risk management.
Reduces impact of seasonal price fluctuations.
113 commodities currently allowed for futures trading in India.

topics.definition: Recession is a decline in economic activity; depression is a severe and prolonged recession.
key_points: Recession: two or more quarters of negative GDP growth.
Characteristics: fall in GDP, industrial output, employment, spending.
Business cycle includes expansion and recession phases.
processes: Economy expands: GDP, employment, incomes rise.
Economy contracts: GDP falls, unemployment increases.
Recovery phase follows trough of business cycle.
examples: Global Depression of 1930s.
Recession of 2008–2009.
facts: Per capita GDP measures standard of living.
Unemployment rises during recession.
Government policies aim to stimulate economy during downturns.

topics.definition: Buying ownership stakes in companies through equity shares, enabling participation in profits and growth.
key_points: Face value: nominal value of share.
Market value: current trading price.
Dividend: share of profit distributed to shareholders.
processes: Company issues shares to raise capital.
Shares traded on stock exchanges (BSE/NSE).
Investors buy/shares through brokers.
examples: IPO: Initial Public Offering – first sale of shares to public.
Buying shares of Reliance, TCS, etc.
facts: Premium: when market price > face value.
Discount: when market price < face value.
Shareholders have voting rights in company decisions.

topics.definition: Insurance provides financial protection against risks to life, health, property, and assets.
key_points: Protects individuals and families from financial loss.
Promotes savings and long-term financial planning.
Supports economic growth by providing capital for infrastructure.
processes: Policyholder pays premium to insurer.
Insurer pools premiums to cover claims of affected policyholders.
Claim is paid out on occurrence of insured event.
examples: Life insurance, health insurance, motor insurance, crop insurance.
Loan-linked insurance (home loan, vehicle loan).
facts: Insurance is based on risk pooling and risk transfer.
Different from banking: insurance covers risk, banking deals with lending/borrowing.
Insurers invest premiums in long-term projects.

topics.definition: Process of buying and selling shares and other securities through stock exchanges.
key_points: Requires trading and demat accounts.
Diversification reduces risk.
Brokers facilitate transactions for a fee.
processes: Open demat and trading accounts with SEBI-registered entities.
Transfer funds, place buy/sell orders.
Shares held electronically in demat account.
examples: Demat account with NSDL or CDSL.
Trading via Zerodha, ICICI Direct, etc.
facts: Demat account can have multiple holders, zero balance.
No account opening charges for basic demat accounts.
Investing in single company is risky.

topics.definition: Stock exchanges are platforms for trading securities and play a key role in economic development.
key_points: Provide liquidity and price discovery.
Help companies raise capital for expansion.
Act as barometer of economic health.
processes: Companies list shares to raise funds.
Investors buy shares, providing capital to companies.
Stock indices (Sensex, Nifty) reflect market trends.
examples: BSE (Bombay Stock Exchange) – oldest in Asia.
NSE (National Stock Exchange) – electronic trading pioneer.
facts: SEBI regulates all stock exchanges in India.
Stock exchanges ensure transparency and investor protection.
They mobilize savings for productive investments.

topics.definition: A unified indirect tax levied on supply of goods and services across India, replacing multiple central and state taxes.
key_points: Dual GST: CGST (Central) and SGST (State).
IGST on inter-state supplies.
Aims to remove cascading effect of taxes.
processes: Tax levied at each stage of value addition.
Input tax credit available at subsequent stages.
Final consumer bears only last-stage GST.
examples: Exempted: alcohol, petroleum products (temporarily).
facts: Implemented on July 1, 2017.
Improves ease of doing business and tax compliance.
Reduces overall tax burden on consumers.

topics.definition: SEBI Complaint Redress System – an online platform for investors to lodge complaints against listed companies or market intermediaries.
key_points: Centralized web-based system.
Complaints forwarded to concerned entity for resolution.
Entities must respond within 30 days.
processes: Investor files complaint on SCORES portal.
SEBI validates and forwards to entity.
Entity replies and files action taken report.
examples: Complaints against brokers, depositories, listed companies.
Non-payment of dividends, transfer delays.
facts: SCORES ensures time-bound grievance resolution.
Investor can track complaint status online.
Stock exchanges must resolve disputes within 15 days.

topics.definition: Systematic saving and investment to ensure financial security after retirement.
key_points: Pension provides regular post-retirement income.
Types: Defined Benefit (DB) and Defined Contribution (DC).
National Pension System (NPS) is a voluntary, long-term scheme.
processes: Estimate retirement corpus needed.
Choose pension plan (NPS, Atal Pension Yojana, etc.).
Contribute regularly during working years.
examples: NPS for government employees (mandatory) and all citizens (voluntary).
Atal Pension Yojana for unorganized sector workers.
facts: PFRDA regulates pension sector.
NPS is portable across jobs and locations.
Swavalamban Yojana provides co-contribution from government.

topics.topic_name: New Pension System (NPS) & Atal Pension Yojana (APY)
topics.definition: Government-backed pension schemes to promote old-age income security, especially for unorganized sector workers.
key_points: NPS: voluntary, market-linked, with choice of investment funds.
APY: guaranteed minimum pension (₹1000–₹5000 per month).
Both schemes encourage long-term savings.
processes: Open NPS/APY account through bank or point of presence.
Make regular contributions.
Receive pension after age 60.
examples: APY: minimum age 18, maximum 40; contribution period ≥20 years.
NPS: Tier I (pension) and Tier II (savings) accounts.
facts: NPS launched in 2004 for government employees, extended to all in 2009.
APY launched in 2015.
Tax benefits available under NPS.
